data.title: Visual Code can't create index.lock while discarding many files
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:09.760Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
xml|Dot|1.9.2
mssql|ms-|1.2.0
PowerShell|ms-|1.4.3
team|ms-|1.122.0
html-preview-vscode|tht|0.1.1

---

Problem.
An error message "fatal error cannot create .git/index.lock file".
Making bulk changes to my files doesn't yield the error.
However, performing undo of edits will produce error in Visual Code.
Discard of 1 file works fine.
Discard of 2 files works fine.
Discard of 60 files does not work fine. It produces the following error...

Sample of one of the files, among the 60 discards...

```
git checkout -q -- k:\repos\projectloc\Installer\Packager\Settings\file.txt
git for-each-ref --format %(refname) %(objectname)
git remote --verbose
git checkout -q -- k:\repos\projectloc\Installer\Packager\Settings\DB_Pkgr_Settings.xml
git show HEAD:Installer/Packager\Settings/PackagersFile.bat
fatal: Unable to create 'k:/repos/projectloc/.git/index.lock': File exists.
```

Another git process seems to be running in this repository, e.g.
an editor opened by 'git commit'. Please make sure all processes
are terminated then try again. If it still fails, a git process
may have crashed in this repository earlier:
remove the file manually to continue.


- If this operation is performed using GitExtensions, with Visual Code open, the same error is produced.
- If this operation is performed using GitExtensions, with Visual Code closed, the same error is NOT produced.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a GIT repository
2. Create a bunch of file edits
3. Undo a majority of them
4. In the OUTPUT window the "cannot create */.git/index.lock file"....

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Feature request: command to programmatically add a folder to workspace

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Today I can call [vscode.openFolder](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/56cfb2754a37f532e17a40c01fc3490b9d63c38f/src/vs/workbench/api/node/extHostApiCommands.ts#L184) to open a folder programmatically:
```
vscode.commands.executeCommand("vscode.openFolder", vscode.Uri.file(path), false);
```

However, I would like to be able to do the same thing with the new multi-root workspace and just _add_ a folder to the workspace. Something like [this](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/424e1ebc28edbee570ffcee769410f00bd287500/src/vs/workbench/browser/actions/workspaceActions.ts#L95), but where I can pass in a Uri

For more context on our scenario, see @chrisdias's comments on this issue: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/13807

NOTE: We realize such a command might restart the extension host, but we don't care if that happens.

data.title: Stage with merge conflicts warning still appears after all conflicts resolved
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Windows Server 2012 R2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Do a git merge/rebase operation that causes merge conflicts
2. Using the Source Control pane, open each file with conflicts, resolve the conflicts, and save
3. Try to stage the file--even though all the conflicts are resolved (and all conflict markers removed), I still get the message "Are you sure you want to stage _______ with merge conflicts?"

This is annoying since I have to take extra time/clicks to confirm the dialog before moving on to the next file.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: use previous commit msg for amend, Fixes #35182

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This is my first pull request! 

Fixes #35182

When you use the amend commit feature, the commit message dialog shows the previous commit's message. If the commit isn't an amend commit or there are no previous commits to get a message from, it defaults to `undefined` (which displays a blank dialog box). 

Hopefully this fits with the coding style for this project. If there are any issues/changes that need to be made to it, let me know.

data.title: Make Git Synchronize useful for a wider audience

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I don't use Synchronize because it can:
- Merge, when I usually want to rebase.
- Push after merging, when I usually want to check the merge went smooth.

The current confirmation dialog really only helps me avoid triggering the action by accident.

It would be more useful if its behavior changed based on the current status (doing a `git fetch` first):
- When there only incoming changes: pull without confirmation dialog.
- When there are only outgoing changes: push with confirmation dialog "There are no incoming changes, do you want to push your outgoing changes?"
- When there are incoming and outgoing changes: pull and merge or rebase with confirmation dialog "There are incoming changes, do you want to merge or rebase your outgoing changes?" (showing Merge and Rebase buttons to choose from)
- When there are neither incoming nor outgoing changes: do nothing, no dialog/message.

This will break the original workflow of push&pull into two steps in the case where there are incoming and outgoing changes, it remains one step in all other cases.

Only the two cases where there is potential harm (merge/rebase needed and push) a confirmation dialog is shown, informing the user what is about to happen.

data.title: View sub-menu blocking other menu items
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:23.027Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Open Visual Studio Code
2.  Click on menu items File, Edit, Selection.  Each items sub-menu opens below menu items, all other 
     menu items are directly accessible.
4.  Click on menu item View, menu items Go, Debug, Tasks and Help are all blocked/hidden by the View 
     sub-menu.  Go, Debug, Tasks and Help are not directly accessible until the View sub-menu is closed 
     by clicking View.  
![viewsubmenu](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32400931/31034248-27d71f5c-a55b-11e7-9591-8877658afed0.png)

perforce|sle|2.2.1
autoimport|ste|1.2.2


Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install plugin egamma/TSLint or sqs/TSLint (TEMP multiroot-compat)
2. create multiple sub projects using lerna to manage dependencies
3. in package B `import * as A from '@pkggrp/A`
4. note that tslint reports on above line: `[ts] cannot find module '@pkggrp/A'`

Reproduces with multiroot or nonmultiroot project (subprojects are not marked as roots for either case)
Does not reproduce in vscode 1.16.1
also reported in [tslint](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-tslint/issues/273)

data.title: Windows magnifier (chromium accessibility events  issue finally  fixed)!!!
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version:
latest
- OS Version:
Windows 10 64 bit
Steps to Reproduce:
When editing text in the vsCode editor while using windows magnifier the focus doesn't follow the insertion cursor.  This was as a result of chromium only emitting the correct accessibility events when a composition based language is used e.g. Chinese.  I created a issue on chromium which has been fixed in the latest chrome release 

bug url:
https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=768125

thanks @alexandrudima for pointing the problem out in another vsCode issue
How/when would this be integrated in vsCode?  I have low vision and it's especially hard to work with the magnifier without automatic following of the insertion point focus... 
1.
open vsCode while using windows magnifier
2.
edit any file using the vsCode editor.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Add "files to exclude" toggle buttons to "Go to File"
data.body:
Please consider adding the toggle buttons from the "files to exclude" input box under SEARCH to the input box for "Go to File" (Ctrl+P).

This would be extremely helpful for those times where I *do* want to find something in node_modules (which inevitably has an enormous number of items in it).

Mockup:

![go-file-file-w-exclude-toggle-buttons](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1298521/31032060-7d75eb2e-a50f-11e7-8c97-847aa2cc0667.png)

Steps to Reproduce:

2.  Try to save the file after the rename.  
3.  Save fails in Code Editor.  The system asks to Cancel, Retry, Discard, Save, or SaveAs.  None of these options work.  The only way to recover is to Cancel and then restart Code.

data.title: x64 bug in extension regex processing causes runaway memory use
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:23.027Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
plsql|cas|0.0.3
jet|dio|0.0.1
xml|Dot|1.9.2
backspace-plusplus|jri|0.0.16
csharp|ms-|1.12.1
PowerShell|ms-|1.4.3
SQR|Cit|0.2.5

(1 theme extensions excluded)


---

Extension processing using x64 version of VS Code improperly handles single quote regex match of "('(?:\\\\'|.)*?')" with a string containing a pound sign character (e.g. 'string#'). Symptom is runaway memory use until the workstation becomes unresponsive.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install SQR 0.2.5 extension
2. Open a file containing a single line:   print 'Emp# '     (+1,1)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: No

data.title: Insiders build not updating on Windows and Mac (works on Linux)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (f7962f0682a76516df51de4856f8ccc5d8ad578a, 2017-09-20T05:10:59.524Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 14.5.0

- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (f7962f0682a76516df51de4856f8ccc5d8ad578a, 2017-09-20T05:24:33.599Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063

Steps to Reproduce
===

1. Download the Insiders build for Mac and Windows from https://code.visualstudio.com/Insiders/
2. Launch and notice that it's not been updated since September 20.
3. Click the gear on the bottom left of the window (the usual place) and select "Check for updates"

### Actual

There are no updates available for Mac and Windows.

Here are the screenshots for the build information. Both Mac and Windows Insiders seem to have been last built on 2017-09-20

![screen shot 2017-09-29 at 9 56 03 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54414/31026753-6ee68798-a4fc-11e7-95b2-975df59b26d2.png)

![screen shot 2017-09-29 at 9 55 34 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54414/31026742-62802a7c-a4fc-11e7-97bd-6ea7f89f2383.png)

### Expected

There should be a new update to match the Linux version (which at this time of filing, is the 2017-09-29 version). **Note that we are using Ubuntu so we have only tested against the .deb file that is generated. The rpm files were not tested**.

- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (caa5656df9e8fa9c556c7eddeb6b4d532814054b, **2017-09-29T05:16:09.696Z**)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-96-generic

![screen shot 2017-09-29 at 9 56 30 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54414/31026778-819ce012-a4fc-11e7-9b7f-b4fae64e4b54.png)

Reproduces without extensions
===

Yes (even removing the ~/.code-insiders folder didn't solve this)

Deleting and reinstalling Insiders doesn't help either.

----

We could get around by building from source but it's more convenient for us to be able to test our extensions against the latest insider builds.

data.title: g++ auto compile only compiles main without other needed cpp files.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1 
  Commit 27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d
- OS Version: Linux (Slackware 14.2)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. write a main.cpp, what.h what.cpp add needed code call it in main.
2. make sure it all in the same directory then click the arrow on the IDE that compiles the code.

C++ does not work. It will only compile the main.cpp leaving out other needed cpp files. Returning an error. 

> In function `main':
> **undefined reference to** _everything in the other needed files_
>error: ld returned 1 exit status

       "cpp": "cd $dir && g++ $fileName -o $fileNameWithoutExt && $dir$fileNameWithoutExt",`

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Hangs when writing optional param with default value in JavaScript comment
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:38:23.027Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
html-snippets|abu|0.1.0
vscode-color|ans|0.4.5
githistory|don|0.2.3
python|don|0.7.0
gitlens|eam|5.3.0
code-runner|for|0.7.2
Lua|key|0.0.9
cpptools|ms-|0.13.0
typescript-javascript-grammar|ms-|0.0.24
material-icon-theme|PKi|2.2.1
java|red|0.10.0

(3 theme extensions excluded)


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Write a JavaScript JsDoc comment on a class member function with a parameter.
2. Edit the documentation of the param to make it optional with a default value.  When typing the equals sign, without having typed the closing brace first, vs code will often hang and need to be restarted.

E.x.
```
class Test {
    /**
     * Some test documentation
     * @async
     * 
     * @param {string} [configFile= - The absolute path of the module's configuration file.
     * @returns {Promise}
     */
    parseModuleConfig(config) {
        return config + 1;
    }
}
```

When typing the **=** in the above comment, vs code hangs.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes
